title: Psalms Chapter 86 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 86 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 86 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 86.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86:1, how does David describe himself when he asks the LORD to hear him?
questions.correctAnswer: Poor and needy
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:1 states that David describes himself as 'poor and needy' when he asks the LORD to hear him.

questions.question: In Psalms 86:5, what qualities of the Lord are mentioned?
options: Good, ready to forgive, plenteous in mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Good, ready to forgive, plenteous in mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:5 highlights that the Lord is good, ready to forgive, and plenteous in mercy to all who call upon Him.

questions.question: Who does David say will come and worship before the LORD, according to Psalms 86:9?
questions.correctAnswer: All nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:9 says that all nations made by God will come and worship before Him.

questions.question: What does David ask the LORD to teach him in Psalms 86:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy way
questions.explanation: In Psalms 86:11, David prays to be taught God's way so he can walk in His truth.

questions.question: What reason does David give in Psalms 86:13 for praising God's mercy?
options: God delivered his soul from the lowest hell
questions.correctAnswer: God delivered his soul from the lowest hell
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:13 says David praises God's mercy because God delivered his soul from the lowest hell.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86:15, which of these is NOT a characteristic of God mentioned?
questions.correctAnswer: Jealousy
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:15 describes God as full of compassion, gracious, longsuffering, and plenteous in mercy and truth, but does not mention jealousy in this verse.

questions.question: What does David request in Psalms 86:16 from the LORD regarding strength?
options: Give thy strength unto thy servant
questions.correctAnswer: Give thy strength unto thy servant
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:16 contains David's request for God to give strength to His servant.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 86:7 says that David will not call upon God in the day of his trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:7 states that in the day of trouble, David will call upon God because He will answer him.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 86:8 says there are many gods like the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:8 declares that among the gods there is none like the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 86:4, David lifts up his soul unto the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:4 states that David lifts up his soul unto the LORD.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 86:12: 'I will praise thee, O Lord my God, with all my ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: Heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:12 says, 'I will praise thee, O Lord my God, with all my heart.'

questions.question: What does David ask to be shown to those who hate him in Psalms 86:17?
questions.correctAnswer: A token for good
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:17 asks God to show a token for good so that those who hate David may see it and be ashamed.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86:14, who has risen against David?
options: The proud and assemblies of violent men
questions.correctAnswer: The proud and assemblies of violent men
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:14 states that the proud and assemblies of violent men have risen against David.

questions.question: In Psalms 86:3, how often does David cry unto the Lord?
questions.correctAnswer: Daily
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:3 says David cries unto the Lord daily and asks for mercy.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86:10, which statement is true about the LORD?
options: Thou art one among many gods
Thou art a god of war
Thou art a god of the sea
questions.correctAnswer: Thou art God alone
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:10 declares that the LORD is great, does wondrous things, and is God alone.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 86 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 86 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Psalms 86 teach us about trusting God during difficult times?
options: Call upon God in the day of trouble because He will answer
Rely only on your own strength to solve problems
Ignore troubles and trust that they will disappear
Seek help only from friends and family
questions.correctAnswer: Call upon God in the day of trouble because He will answer
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:7 encourages believers to call upon God in times of trouble, assuring that He will answer. This is supported by verses 1 and 6 where David asks God to hear his prayer and preserve his soul.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of unworthiness. Based on Psalms 86, what truth would you share about God's mercy?
options: God is good, ready to forgive, and plenteous in mercy to all who call on Him
God only shows mercy to the perfect
Mercy is earned through works alone
God's mercy is limited to certain people
questions.correctAnswer: God is good, ready to forgive, and plenteous in mercy to all who call on Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:5 highlights God's readiness to forgive and his abundant mercy to everyone who calls on Him, reassuring believers of His compassionate nature. This truth encourages humility and trust.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86, how should we respond to God's guidance in our daily walk?
options: Ask God to teach us His way and walk in His truth
Ignore God's instructions and follow our own desires
Change God's word to fit our lifestyle
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God to teach us His way and walk in His truth
questions.explanation: Verse 11 shows David's desire to be taught God's way and to walk in truth, emphasizing obedience and a heart united in reverence for God. This supports a lifestyle of integrity and faithfulness.

questions.question: What does Psalms 86 say about God’s uniqueness compared to other gods?
options: There is none like God; no works like His works
God is just one among many gods
Other gods can do the same works as God
God's works are less important than human works
questions.correctAnswer: There is none like God; no works like His works
questions.explanation: Verse 8 declares that among the gods there is none like the LORD and no works like His. This teaches believers to trust in God's unique power and sovereignty.

questions.question: How can a believer express gratitude to God based on Psalms 86?
options: Praise God with all heart and glorify His name forever
Keep gratitude private and never speak of it
Thank only when receiving material blessings
Praise only in church but not personally
questions.correctAnswer: Praise God with all heart and glorify His name forever
questions.explanation: Verse 12 encourages full-hearted praise and eternal glorification of God’s name, showing the importance of sincere gratitude in personal devotion and worship.

questions.question: In Psalms 86, what does David ask God to unite his heart to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Fear God's name
questions.explanation: Verse 11 includes David's prayer that God unite his heart to fear His name, reflecting humility and reverence essential for godly living.

questions.question: What attitude towards enemies does Psalms 86 demonstrate?
options: Trust God to shame those who hate and show His help
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to shame those who hate and show His help
questions.explanation: Verse 17 shows a request for God to give a sign of good so that enemies see and are ashamed, teaching believers to rely on God’s justice rather than personal retaliation.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 86 teaches that God is full of compassion, gracious, longsuffering, and abundant in mercy and truth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 15 explicitly describes God as compassionate, gracious, longsuffering, and plenteous in mercy and truth, highlighting His loving nature toward His people.

questions.question: How does Psalms 86 portray the relationship between prayer and God's hearing?
options: God listens attentively to prayer and supplications
God hears only after long delays
questions.correctAnswer: God listens attentively to prayer and supplications
questions.explanation: Verse 6 asks God to give ear to the prayer and attend to the supplications, showing that God is attentive and responsive to sincere prayer.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by prideful and violent opposition. According to Psalms 86, what can they rely on?
options: Their own ability to fight back
Joining the opposition to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: God’s compassion and saving strength
questions.explanation: Verse 14 describes the proud and violent rising against David, while verse 16 petitions God for mercy, strength, and salvation, illustrating reliance on God in adversity.

questions.question: What does Psalms 86 say about the nations and their relation to God?
options: All nations made by God will come and worship Him
Nations should worship their own gods
Worship is not necessary for nations
questions.correctAnswer: All nations made by God will come and worship Him
questions.explanation: Verse 9 clearly states that all nations God has made will come and worship before Him, promoting evangelism and the global recognition of God’s glory.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 86 teaches that God alone is great and does wondrous things.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 10 affirms that God is great and performs wondrous deeds, emphasizing His unique power and encouraging faith and worship.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 86, how should believers seek help when feeling poor and needy?
options: Bow down and ask God to hear their prayer
Rely only on their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Bow down and ask God to hear their prayer
questions.explanation: Verse 1 teaches that the humble and needy should bow and call on God, trusting Him to hear and respond, which is foundational to prayer and dependence on God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 86 encourage believers to view their personal holiness in relation to God's protection?
options: Preserve my soul, for I am holy; save your servant who trusts in you
Holiness is irrelevant to God's protection
Protection depends on wealth and status
questions.correctAnswer: Preserve my soul, for I am holy; save your servant who trusts in you
questions.explanation: Verse 2 links personal holiness with God's preservation and salvation of those who trust Him, highlighting the importance of faithfulness and trust.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "For great is thy mercy toward me: and thou hast delivered my soul from the ______ hell."
questions.correctAnswer: lowest
questions.explanation: Verse 13 uses the phrase 'lowest hell' to describe the deliverance God provides, emphasizing His mercy and saving power.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 86 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 86.

questions.question: In Psalms 86:1, David calls on the LORD to 'bow down thine ear' because he feels what?
questions.correctAnswer: Poor and needy
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:1 explicitly states David calls on the LORD to hear him because he is 'poor and needy,' expressing humility and dependence.

questions.question: Which characteristic of God is emphasized in Psalms 86:5 as being 'plenteous' towards all who call upon Him?
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:5 highlights that God is 'plenteous in mercy' to all who call upon Him, underscoring His abundant compassion.

questions.question: Psalms 86:8 declares that among the gods, there is none like whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:8 affirms the uniqueness of the LORD among all so-called gods, highlighting monotheism and God's incomparable nature.

questions.question: What action do 'all nations' take according to Psalms 86:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Worship before the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:9 foretells that all nations made by God shall come and worship before Him, indicating a universal acknowledgment of His sovereignty.

questions.question: In Psalms 86:11, what does David request to be taught?
questions.correctAnswer: The way of the LORD
questions.explanation: David prays in Psalms 86:11 to be taught God's way so that he may walk in His truth, showing a desire for guidance and obedience.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86:13, from where has God delivered David's soul?
questions.correctAnswer: The lowest hell
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:13 declares God's mercy in delivering David's soul from the lowest hell, a term often translated as 'Sheol' or the realm of the dead.

questions.question: Psalms 86:15 describes the LORD as full of several attributes. Which of the following is NOT listed?
questions.correctAnswer: Jealousy
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:15 lists the LORD as full of compassion, graciousness, longsuffering, mercy, and truth but does not mention jealousy in this verse.

questions.question: What is the significance of the word 'merciful' in Psalms 86:3 in relation to David's prayer life?
options: It reflects God's wrath against enemies
It shows David's daily dependence on God's kindness
It implies God's indifference to prayers
It indicates a one-time request for help
questions.correctAnswer: It shows David's daily dependence on God's kindness
questions.explanation: In Psalms 86:3, David asks for mercy because he cries to the LORD daily, showing ongoing reliance on God's mercy.

questions.question: Which literary device is predominantly used in Psalms 86:5 with the phrases 'ready to forgive' and 'plenteous in mercy'?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:5 uses synonymous parallelism by pairing 'ready to forgive' with 'plenteous in mercy,' reinforcing God's compassionate nature.

questions.question: Psalms 86:7 states, 'In the day of my trouble I will call upon thee.' This reflects which broader biblical theme?
options: God as a refuge in times of distress
questions.correctAnswer: God as a refuge in times of distress
questions.explanation: This verse expresses trust in God as a refuge and helper during trouble, a recurring theme throughout Scripture (e.g., Psalm 46).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 86:10 emphasizes that God is one among many great gods.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:10 asserts that God is 'God alone,' emphasizing monotheism and His unique sovereignty, not one among many gods.

questions.question: The plea in Psalms 86:16 to 'give thy strength unto thy servant' most directly connects to which ancient Near Eastern cultural value?
options: Invoking divine empowerment for faithful service
questions.correctAnswer: Invoking divine empowerment for faithful service
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, strength from a deity was understood as divine empowerment to fulfill duties; David requests this for faithful service in Psalms 86:16.

questions.question: How does Psalms 86:12's declaration to praise God 'with all my heart' relate to the Shema found in Deuteronomy 6:5?
options: It contradicts the Shema's call to love God
It echoes the Shema's emphasis on wholehearted devotion
It introduces a new concept not found in Deuteronomy
It focuses on communal rather than individual worship
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the Shema's emphasis on wholehearted devotion
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:12 reflects wholehearted love and praise for God, paralleling Deuteronomy 6:5's command to love the LORD with all one's heart.

questions.question: Which feature of Psalms 86 shows it functions as a penitential prayer typical of David's compositions?
options: Its focus on God's wrath and punishment
Its cry for mercy and confession of need
questions.correctAnswer: Its cry for mercy and confession of need
questions.explanation: Psalms 86 includes pleas for mercy and acknowledgment of personal need, hallmarks of a penitential prayer style attributed to David.

questions.question: Psalms 86:17 asks God to 'shew me a token for good.' In biblical typology, what can this 'token' be associated with?
options: The sign of the rainbow in Genesis
The Passover lamb's blood in Exodus
The Ark of the Covenant as a symbol of God's presence
The pillar of cloud and fire in Exodus
questions.correctAnswer: The Ark of the Covenant as a symbol of God's presence
questions.explanation: The 'token for good' in Psalms 86:17 can be typologically linked to visible signs of God's presence and favor, such as the Ark of the Covenant.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 86 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 86 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86:5, which attribute of God is emphasized as His readiness towards those who call upon Him?
options: He is ready to forgive and plenteous in mercy
He is slow to answer prayers
He is only merciful to the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: He is ready to forgive and plenteous in mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:5 highlights God's readiness to forgive and His abundant mercy toward all who call upon Him. This is consistent with Exodus 34:6, where God is described as merciful and gracious; also with Lamentations 3:22-23 emphasizing God's steadfast mercy; with Ephesians 2:4 describing God as rich in mercy; and 1 John 1:9 affirming God's readiness to forgive.

questions.question: In Psalms 86:10, God is described as doing wondrous things and being:
options: A god of the heavens only
questions.correctAnswer: God alone
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:10 states that God is great and does wondrous things and that He is God alone, affirming monotheism. This aligns with Deuteronomy 6:4's Shema, Isaiah 45:5 declaring there is no God besides Him, John 17:3 affirming eternal life through knowing the only true God, and 1 Timothy 2:5 emphasizing one God and one mediator.

questions.question: What does David request from the LORD in Psalms 86:11 to help him walk in God's truth?
questions.correctAnswer: Teach me thy way
questions.explanation: David asks God to teach him His way so that he may walk in truth (Psalms 86:11). This reflects a desire for divine guidance consistent with Proverbs 3:5-6 urging trust in the LORD for direction, Psalm 25:4-5 seeking God's paths, John 14:6 where Jesus is the way and truth, and James 1:5 encouraging believers to ask God for wisdom.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86:13, what has God done for David that reveals His mercy?
options: Delivered my soul from the lowest hell
questions.correctAnswer: Delivered my soul from the lowest hell
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:13 testifies to God's mercy in delivering David's soul from the lowest hell, signifying salvation from death or Sheol. This corresponds with Jonah 2:2 where God delivers from the depths, Psalm 103:4 emphasizing redemption from destruction, Romans 10:13 about calling on the Lord to be saved, and Revelation 1:18 where Christ has the keys of death and Hades.

questions.question: Which description best fits God’s character in Psalms 86:15?
options: Full of compassion, gracious, longsuffering, plenteous in mercy and truth
questions.correctAnswer: Full of compassion, gracious, longsuffering, plenteous in mercy and truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:15 provides a rich portrait of God as compassionate, gracious, longsuffering, and abundant in mercy and truth. This agrees with Exodus 34:6-7 highlighting these attributes, Lamentations 3:22-23 on steadfast love, 2 Peter 3:9 on God's patience, and John 1:14 where grace and truth came through Jesus Christ.

questions.question: Psalms 86:8 declares there is no god like the LORD among the gods. How does this statement serve as an apologetic?
options: It asserts the uniqueness and supremacy of the LORD over all false gods
It acknowledges the equality of all gods
It encourages worship of many gods
questions.correctAnswer: It asserts the uniqueness and supremacy of the LORD over all false gods
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:8 affirms the LORD’s uniqueness and incomparable works as a defense against polytheism. This is consistent with Isaiah 44:6 declaring God as the only God, Psalm 96:5 rejecting idols, 1 Corinthians 8:4 emphasizing one true God, and John 1:1-3 affirming the Creator's uniqueness.

questions.question: What does David request God to do in Psalms 86:16 to strengthen him?
options: Give thy strength unto thy servant
questions.correctAnswer: Give thy strength unto thy servant
questions.explanation: David asks God to give strength to His servant (Psalms 86:16), showing dependence on divine empowerment rather than human ability. This aligns with Isaiah 40:29 granting strength to the weary, Philippians 4:13 on strength through Christ, Nehemiah 8:10 describing the LORD’s strength as salvation, and 2 Corinthians 12:9 revealing God's power made perfect in weakness.

questions.question: In Psalms 86:9, who will come and worship before the LORD, according to the text?
options: All nations whom God has made
questions.correctAnswer: All nations whom God has made
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:9 declares that all nations created by God will come and worship Him, pointing to the universal scope of God's reign. This is echoed in Isaiah 2:2-3 envisioning all nations worshiping God, Revelation 7:9 describing a great multitude from every nation, Matthew 28:19 commissioning disciples to all nations, and Philippians 2:10-11 affirming every knee shall bow to Jesus.

questions.question: How does Psalms 86:4 describe David’s attitude toward God?
options: He lifts up his soul to the LORD in rejoicing
questions.correctAnswer: He lifts up his soul to the LORD in rejoicing
questions.explanation: David expresses lifting up his soul to God with joy and trust (Psalms 86:4), indicating heartfelt devotion. This is consistent with Psalm 25:1 committing the soul to God, Psalm 42:11 encouraging hope in God, Luke 1:46 Mary's song of rejoicing in God, and Philippians 4:4 exhorting joy in the Lord always.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 86:3 says, 'Be merciful unto me, O Lord: for I cry unto thee _____.'
questions.correctAnswer: daily
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:3 states David cries unto the LORD daily, emphasizing persistent prayer. This is affirmed in Daniel 6:10 where Daniel prays three times daily, Luke 18:1 teaching persistent prayer, 1 Thessalonians 5:17 commanding to pray without ceasing, and Psalm 55:17 praying evening, morning, and noon.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86:2, why does David ask God to preserve his soul?
options: Because he is holy and trusts in God
Because he is wealthy and powerful
questions.correctAnswer: Because he is holy and trusts in God
questions.explanation: David appeals for soul preservation because he is holy and trusts God (Psalms 86:2), showing reliance on God's sanctifying power. This aligns with 1 Peter 1:15-16 calling believers to holiness, Romans 8:38-39 on confidence in God’s love, Psalm 34:18 regarding God’s nearness to the brokenhearted, and Hebrews 11:6 on faith trusting God.

questions.question: What is the significance of 'the assemblies of violent men' mentioned in Psalms 86:14?
options: They represent hostile forces that oppose God’s people
questions.correctAnswer: They represent hostile forces that oppose God’s people
questions.explanation: Psalms 86:14 describes hostile violent men rising against David, representing opposition to God's servant. This reflects the biblical motif of spiritual and earthly opposition found in Psalm 37:12-15, John 15:18 warning of hatred by the world, Ephesians 6:12 about spiritual warfare, and Romans 8:35 concerning trials against believers.

questions.question: How does Psalms 86:12 express the scope of David’s praise to God?
options: With all my heart and forevermore
questions.correctAnswer: With all my heart and forevermore
questions.explanation: David commits to praising God wholeheartedly and eternally (Psalms 86:12), reflecting total devotion. This is consistent with Psalm 111:1 praising the LORD with the whole heart, Psalm 145:1-2 committing to continual praise, Revelation 5:13 showing eternal worship, and Colossians 3:16 encouraging heartfelt thanksgiving.

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the prayer tone of Psalms 86?
options: A humble appeal for mercy and guidance
A declaration of vengeance against enemies
questions.correctAnswer: A humble appeal for mercy and guidance
questions.explanation: The entire chapter is a humble prayer asking for mercy, protection, and instruction (Psalms 86:1-17). This is echoed in Micah 6:8 emphasizing humility, Luke 18:13 showing the tax collector’s humble prayer, James 4:6 teaching God gives grace to the humble, and Psalm 25:9 about God guiding the humble.

questions.question: According to Psalms 86:7, what is David’s confidence in calling to God in times of trouble?
questions.correctAnswer: That God will answer him
questions.explanation: David confidently calls on God in trouble, expecting an answer (Psalms 86:7). This trust aligns with Psalm 34:17 where God hears the righteous, Jeremiah 33:3 promising answers when called upon, John 10:27-28 describing Jesus hearing His sheep, and Romans 8:28 assuring God's working for good.
